content.description: Climb a chossy arete. Layback a nice fingercrack. Then power through a horizontal roof section, clipping nearby bolts. Cut feet and pull the roof.
content.protection: 6 bolts. The top takes optional horizontals #1-#2 but is unnecessary.
content.location: Far left side of the crag. A very obvious roof.

content.description:
A sustained 5.10C on positive holds. Get through the V3-4 boulder problem move then bash the overhanging jugs to the last bolt. Pull a spicy move off some pockets and climb easy terrain to the anchors. Beta: Don't slow down. 

  Some chossy sections. Make sure people are not below the climber and the belayer is wearing a helmet.
A technical 5.10. At the 5th bolt, traverse to the right and begin to join "The Diving Bell and the Butterfly"
An excellent, dirty, and varied crack. A hard start (for 5.8) followed by a 5.8 layback, followed by a short offwidth section, followed by a moderate roof.
content.protection: Standard Rack. At least one #4 will make it a little easier. Lots of runners.
content.location: Left facing dihedral. Should be followed by a second.

climbs.name: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly

content.description: Very fun climbing through the crux to the 3rd bolt, at which point the grade eases up.  The final slab can be dirty (but easily doable due to the good feet).  Anchors shared with Green Hornet & Lost My Lizard.
content.location: Look for the route that goes up the vertical face right of Lost My Lizard (10a) and Green Hornet (5.8, a ledge-y crack that goes up to the right to meet the anchors for Lost My Lizard and The Diving Bell)

content.description: Fun but dirty, some loose rock, not well traveled
content.location: 100' to the right of Green Hornet

content.description: All day sun. Can find shade all day too. Hardly ever visited. The trail is difficult to stay on but is still an easy approach.
